forecast.rationale:
Baseline: Indian kinetic actions into Pakistan’s provinces are rare. The most salient precedent is the February 2019 Balakot airstrike in KP; most routine cross-border fire occurs along the LoC opposite Pakistan-administered Kashmir (which would not count for this question). On a pure base-rate, the monthly probability is very low.

Current context (from the research assistant): India has launched a diplomatic push (seven all-party delegations to 32 countries between May 21 and June 5), the PM articulated a tougher doctrine (“no tolerance for terror that hides under nuclear blackmail”), and the Army Chief reportedly gave Western Command ‘full authority’ to execute kinetic retaliation to any future ceasefire violations. These signals raise the conditional probability of a localized retaliatory strike if Pakistan initiates a provocation—especially along the IB/Working Boundary where Pakistani territory is in Punjab, one of the qualifying provinces.

Why not higher: Even amid heightened tensions, India usually calibrates to avoid escalation into Pakistan proper due to nuclear risks and international pressure. The ongoing diplomatic offensive suggests New Delhi is courting international support and managing escalation, not seeking an immediate cross-border strike. Most firing, if it occurs, is likelier along the LoC into Pakistan-administered Kashmir (excluded by this question). Absent a major provocation, deep strikes into KP/Punjab or cross-IB artillery into Pakistani Punjab remain less likely than not in any single month.

Why not lower: The explicit delegation of authority to Western Command to retaliate to ceasefire violations makes a cross-IB kinetic response more plausible if there is firing from Pakistan’s side along the Working Boundary. Additionally, a high-profile terror incident in India in late May or June could trigger a Balakot-style punitive action into KP or Punjab.

What would move me up: Credible reports of (1) significant Pakistani ceasefire violations along the IB/Working Boundary (Jammu–Sialkot/Lahore sectors), (2) a major terror attack in India with rapid attribution to Pakistan-based groups, (3) unusual Indian Air Force posturing (airspace closures, dispersal, CAP surge), or (4) official Indian rhetoric signaling imminent retaliation. Clear evidence that India’s diplomatic outreach is to pre-justify a strike would also raise odds.

What would move me down: Verified de-escalation steps (hotline statements reaffirming the ceasefire, pullbacks), absence of significant incidents by mid-June, strong international mediation outcomes, or indications that any Indian retaliation will stay confined to Pakistan-administered Kashmir.

Netting these factors, I place extra weight on the status quo (no strike into the four provinces) but acknowledge elevated risk given posture and delegation of authority.
